snippet: Files released by House investigators include an email telling Mary T. Barra, now the chief executive, of steering problems in 2011.
abstract: Files released by House Energy and Commerce Committee investigators show that Mary T Barra, new chief executive of General Motors, may have been aware earlier than suggested of dangerous flaw in ignition switch of small cars, which led to recall that would eventually cover 2.6 million cars; documents detail years of deliberations over defect not disclosed until 2014.

byline.original: By HILARY STOUT and BILL VLASIC
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Matthew L. Wald, Danielle Ivory, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Hiroko Tabuchi, Christopher Jensen and Rachel Abrams.

lead_paragraph: Files released by House investigators include an email telling Mary T. Barra, now the chief executive, of steering problems in 2011.

headline.main: G.M. Documents Reveal Years of Talks on Defect
